- EDF appoints Claude Laruelle as new CFO (EDF). EDF announced the appointment of Claude Laruelle as new CFO. Claude Laruelle, former CFO of Veolia until September 2024, will replace Xavier Girre who left EDF to become CEO of Suez.

- EVN releases 9M2024/25 results and reiterates guidance (EVN). EBITDA was €714m (+14% yoy) mainly due to normalisation of supply activity. EBIT was €447m (+18% yoy) while net income group share was €435m (-9% yoy) due to the reduction in the dividend from Verbund. Net debt was €1,119m, down from €1,129m at end-September 2024). At the divisional level, EVN KG (supply) contribution improved at +€1.5m (vs -€107m last year), however implied 3Q2024/25 contribution was slightly lower (+€13m vs + €21m). Generation EBITDA was down 33% yoy due to declining power prices and lower generation volumes. The closing of the sale of the WTE division is now expected withing the next 6 months. EVN reiterated FY2024/25 guidance where it expects Group net result within a range of €400-440m (BBG Cons at €432m).

- E.ON successfully issues €1.1bn of green bonds (E.ON). E.ON successfully issued two green bond tranches with a combined volume of €1.1bn - a €500m green bond maturing in September 2031 with a coupon of 3.0% and a €600m green bond maturing in

September 2035 with a coupon of \(3.5\%\) . This is the second and final public Euro transaction this year covering E.ON's funding needs for 2025. The funding volume of €3.0bn in 2025 remains below the usual annual funding level of €3.5- 5bn due to prefunding in 2024. Around \(70\%\) of 2025 funding was covered with green bonds, significantly surpassing the target of more than \(50\%\) . The transactions attracted strong investor demand with a combined orderbook of over €2.75bn.

- RWE CEO sees no need for writedowns on major US offshore project (Reuters). RWE sees no need to write down a 3GW project in the United States, its CEO said, just days after the US government ordered bigger rival Orsted to stop construction on an advanced site. The so-called Community Offshore Wind project, which RWE owns in a \(73\% - 27\%\) ownership split with National Grid has been put on ice and no investment decision has been taken, Markus Krebber told journalists. "We have pulled the plug," Krebber said with regard to Community Offshore Wind, reiterating earlier comments that the construction on the project had not yet started. Krebber said he therefore saw no need to write down the project, which has a book value of €800m. He said that if political opposition persisted against the sector it could become a matter for the courts given lease payments have been made in the past.

- Acciona Energia reorganizes its alliance with The Blue Circle to focus on the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam (El Economista). Acciona Energia and The Blue Circle have reorganized their partnership to focus independently in different markets. Acciona Energia will now control all renewable energy projects in the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, while The Blue Circle will focus on Sri Lanka, Malaysia, and Cambodia. This change follows their 2022 agreement, when Acciona acquired \(50\%\) of The Blue Circle, which then had a 3.8GW project portfolio across six countries plus Indonesia. The reorganization strengthens Acciona's presence in Asia-Pacific, a key region for its global growth and energy transition strategy. Acciona Energia is particularly focused on expanding its wind and solar projects in the Philippines, aiming to accelerate growth in the coming years.

- Italy excludes Chinese components from new solar tender (Montel). Italy approved on Wednesday new rules for a second Fer X green capacity auction to take place by the end of the year but banned solar projects whose main components are of Chinese origin. Solar projects larger than 1 MW must have PV modules that were not assembled in China and cells and inverters that are not of Chinese origin to be eligible to participate in the new tender under the Fer X scheme, the country's energy ministry said. The measure aimed to enhance the resilience of Italy's solar energy sector and reduce dependency on third-country supply chains, it said. This auction would cover up to \(20\%\) of the maximum solar capacity available under the scheme, said the ministry.

batteries. Elpower Energy plans to "immediately" begin constructing 300MWh of battery storage capacity across three projects, with plans to reach final investment decisions on up to 1GWh of additional capacity by the end of 2025.

- UK household energy price cap to rise \(2\%\) despite falling wholesale gas, power prices (Platts). Ofgem announced a \(2\%\) increase to the energy price cap for October to December, despite a \(2\%\) fall in wholesale energy prices. The increase is driven by higher power balancing costs as well as the extension of the Warm Home Discount initiative, Ofgem said Aug. 27. Ofgem said the average annual UK household gas and power bill in Q4 will be capped at £1,755/year, up £35 from the current quarter.

- Renewing the ban on acquisition only tariffs after March 2026 (Ofgem). The consultation proposes extending Standard Licence Condition (SLC) 22B, the Ban on Acquisition-only Tariffs (BAT), for 12 months until 31 March 2027, unless compelling evidence supports its removal. Stakeholders are also invited to comment on extending the BAT's Market-wide Derogation for the same period. The consultation focuses solely on the short-term renewal or removal of SLC 22B, not its long-term future, which will be addressed separately in ongoing work on future price protection. Input is sought from energy suppliers, third-party intermediaries, consumer groups, other stakeholders, and the public interested in the domestic retail energy supply market.

- Ofwat agrees payment plan with Thames over record fines (Utility Week). Thames Water has agreed with Ofwat to repay £122.7m in penalties in instalments, with \(20\%\) (£24.5m) due by 30 September 2025 and the full amount by March 2030 at the latest. Repayment could be accelerated if the company restructures or enters a special administration regime (SAR), requiring payment within 30 days of implementation for restructuring or 30 days after SAR has completed. The fines include £104.5m for wastewater permit breaches and £18.2m related to dividend payments. Ofwat's Lynn Parker emphasized that the plan holds Thames Water accountable while considering its ongoing recapitalisation. The company assured that penalties will not be passed on to customers.

- Political system 'cannot cope' with Cunliffe reforms (Utility Week). Chris Goodall, a former Competition Commission tribunal member, warns that implementing the Cunliffe review's recommendations for the water sector will cause unprecedented disruption, challenging the capacity of the UK political system. He questions whether the political system can cope to deliver the radical changes proposed by the Independent Water Commission, noting that no other industry has faced such a transformation. Goodall highlights that 38 of the 88 recommendations require primary legislation, demanding significant parliamentary time and political will. He also points out that water regulation is currently politically unpopular, making reform even more difficult.

- FCA opens UK investigation into Drax accounts (FT). UK markets regulators have opened an investigation into Drax over the UK energy company's sourcing of wood for biomass pellets following accusations made by a former senior executive. The FTSE 250 group said on Thursday it had been notified by the FCA that the agency had begun a probe covering the period from January 2022 to March 2024. It will also cover the company's annual results for the financial years 2021-23. Drax said it would co-operate with the FCA.

- Dutch crisis eases as caretaker premier wins confidence vote (Bloomberg). Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof and his cabinet survived a no-confidence vote, easing concerns about a complete collapse of the country's caretaker government. The outcome of the confidence vote turns attention to campaigning for snap elections on Oct. 29 to ultimately resolve the political crisis. The power vacuum in The Netherlands continues, and the political fragmentation was laid bare, with deep rifts revealed during hours of debate among the 15 parties in the parliament.

- Poland to boost wind capacity despite presidential veto, PM says (Reuters). Poland will "radically increase" wind power capacity despite last week's decision by President Karol Nawrocki to veto a bill aimed at easing rules for building onshore wind farms, Prime Minister Donald Tusk said on Wednesday. The vetoed bill would have cut the distance required between planned installations and residential locations. "We will radically increase onshore wind capacity because this is the cheapest source of electricity," Tusk told reporters. He said the government was working on a resolution to allow more efficient wind turbines to be installed at existing wind farms. Government resolutions do not require legislative backing by parliament and so are not subject to presidential approval.

- Microsoft plan to turn wind farms into mini AI data centres: 'massive power opportunity' (Recharge). A team at Microsoft proposes transforming wind farms into mini-AI data centres by installing modular computing hardware directly at wind sites, a concept called "AI Greenferencing." This approach leverages wind's "massive, underutilised power opportunity" to run AI inferencing tasks, reducing reliance on traditional grids and addressing power delivery challenges. Running AI at the power source offers a new revenue stream for wind farm owners and cost-effective, sustainable power for AI providers. Wind's variable but predictable output aligns well

with Al workloads, capex should be no higher than for a traditional data centre, opex could be lower if wind farm operators are trained for data centre maintenance and cost of power could be cheaper compared to PPAs due to lower curtailment. Microsoft estimates up to 6.7m GPUs could be deployed at suitable wind farms.

- Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners shows appetite for one of offshore wind's frontier markets (Recharge). Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners (CIP) has agreed to develop a major offshore wind project in Vietnam in partnership with state-run oil company Petrovietnam. The joint development agreement is geared toward development of an offshore wind project in Vietnam's south-central region. CIP described the project as still in an early phase of development and subject to relevant regulatory approvals, but added that it is "expected to be among Vietnam's first offshore wind initiatives." Vietnam's national Power Development Plan includes a commitment to develop 6GW of offshore wind by 2030, rising to more than 70GW by 2050.

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

This research publication covers six or more companies. For valuation methodology and other company disclosures: Please visit: https://bernstein-autonomous.bluematrix.com/sellside/Disclosures.action. Or, you can also write to the Director of Compliance, Bernstein Institutional Services LLC, 245 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10167.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance

Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
